pullRequest.body:
Define the maximal nilpotent ideal of Lie algebras
---
In this PR, I define the maximal nilpotent ideal of a Lie algebra.
A closely related concept—the radical of a Lie algebra (the maximal solvable ideal)—is already defined in Algebra/Lie/Solvable.lean.

I prove the analogous results for the maximal nilpotent ideal that have been established for the radical.

This work is part of the framework:
https://github.com/orgs/leanprover-community/projects/17
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ LieIdeal.nilpotent_iff_le_max_nilpotent_ideal`

`+ instMaxNilpotentSubmoduleIsNilpotent`

<details>

```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks!

I've given a fairly nitpicky review, mostly to highlight some points of style which I think can only be learned through review but this is very nice work.

We'll be able to merge this very quickly after you've looked at these suggestions.

Thanks!

I've given a fairly nitpicky review, mostly to highlight some points of style which I think can only be learned through review but this is very nice work.

We'll be able to merge this very quickly after you've looked at these suggestions.

Since `LieSubmodule.wellFoundedGT_of_noetherian` is an instance, it is supposed to be picked up automatically. Usually (though not always) something is not quite right when we need to address an instance by name. In this case we can golf as follows:
```suggestion
  have hwf := CompleteLattice.WellFoundedGT.isSupClosedCompact (LieSubmodule R L M) inferInstance
```
but we still shouldn't need that final `inferInstance`: the final argument to `CompleteLattice.WellFoundedGT.isSupClosedCompact` should be a typeclass argument rather than an explicit argument.

The reason for these minor issues is that it is only relatively recently that we promoted the concept of a well founded order to a typeclass (as `WellFoundedGT`).

In time, we'll smooth out these wrinkles.

In this case the two goals are very close to being just instances, so we should try to avoid doing things manually. We can golf as follows:
```suggestion
  refine hwf { N : LieSubmodule R L M | IsNilpotent L N } ⟨⊥, ?_⟩ fun N₁ h₁ N₂ h₂ => ?_ <;>
  simp_all <;> infer_instance
```
provided we first make the following change higher up:
```diff
- instance instIsNilpotentAdd (M₁ M₂ : LieSubmodule R L M) [IsNilpotent L M₁] [IsNilpotent L M₂] :
-     IsNilpotent L (M₁ + M₂ : LieSubmodule R L M) := by
+ instance instIsNilpotentSup (M₁ M₂ : LieSubmodule R L M) [IsNilpotent L M₁] [IsNilpotent L M₂] :
+    IsNilpotent L (M₁ ⊔ M₂ : LieSubmodule R L M) := by
```

The lesson here is that we should have used `⊔` rather than `+` for this instance because that is the more general operation, i.e., it will interface better with the lattice theory API (where there is not `+` in general).

How about we do this first for Lie modules like the rest, i.e., higher up:
```lean
@[simp] lemma maxNilpotentSubmodule_eq_top_of_isNilpotent [LieModule.IsNilpotent L M] :
    maxNilpotentSubmodule R L M = ⊤ := by
  rw [eq_top_iff]
  apply le_sSup
  simpa
```
and then just use that here.

For better or worse, our naming scheme mixes camelCase and snake_case so this should be:
```suggestion
theorem LieIdeal.isNilpotent_iff_maxNilpotentIdeal [IsNoetherian R L] (I : LieIdeal R L) :
```
(The idea is that the underscores separate terms in lemma names so we want to preserve that `maxNilpotentIdeal` is single term.)
Similar remarks in one or two other places.

No need for `apply` when you have the exact term to hand:
```suggestion
    IsNilpotent L (maxNilpotentIdeal R L) :=
  maxNilpotentSubmoduleIsNilpotent R L L
```
(what you had is fine too of course, this is just a nitpick)

```suggestion
    IsNilpotent L I ↔ I ≤ maxNilpotentIdeal R L :=
  nilpotent_iff_le_maxNilpotentSubmodule R L L I
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Algebra/Lie): define the maximal nilpotent ideal of Lie algebras
